nodes.text: Aggregate production efficiency is desirable in a wide variety of circumstances provided taxes are set optimally; optimal commodity taxes imply marginal rates of substitution need not equal marginal rates of transformation but still imply desirability of aggregate production efficiency
Context: integrate taxation, public investment, and welfare economics to study joint choice of taxes and public production to maximize social welfare
Method (one-consumer geometric): analyze a two-commodity economy with government-controlled production, plot offer curve and production frontier to show optimal consumption is on production frontier

Method (one-consumer algebraic): formulate welfare as indirect function v(q) of consumer prices q, impose production constraint G(z)=0, market clearing x(q)=y+z, and use Lagrangian maximization to derive first-order conditions

Assumptions summary used for main results: private production has constant returns and competitive zero profits, commodity taxes only (initially), consumer and producer demands homogeneous degree zero, continuous utility and demand functions, government may not use lump-sum taxes
One-consumer geometric conclusion: given offer curve and production set, any interior consumption point is dominated by a point on the production frontier, so optimal point lies on frontier
Algebraic derivation step: consumer indirect welfare derivatives Vk expressed in terms of marginal utilities and demand derivatives and consumer budget constraint

Result: Lagrangian first-order conditions imply X times (public marginal rates of transformation minus private marginal rates) equals zero, so if multiplier X nonzero then marginal rates of transformation are equal across public and private production (aggregate production efficiency)

Claim about optimal tax structure: first-order conditions relate consumer price marginal welfare Vk to cost of meeting demand changes, equivalently (when welfare is individualistic) marginal tax revenue per unit divided by quantity is constant across commodities

Extension to many consumers: represent social welfare as indirect function V(q)=U(x1(q),...,xH(q)), continuity of aggregate demand and V(q) allows the one-consumer conclusions to carry over under a mild additional assumption ensuring multiplier X not zero

Theorem (existence and efficiency): under technical assumptions (continuous utility, closed production set, bounded attainable set) an optimum exists and, provided V changes with some price (no unconstrained local maximum), optimal production is on production frontier (weak efficiency)

Interpretation of tax rule: optimal taxes can be characterized by constant proportionality of marginal welfare change to change in revenue at constant producer prices; this yields practical testable conditions and connects to Ramsey-Samuelson demand formulations

Counterexamples and limitations: examples show optimal production can be interior (not on frontier) when assumptions fail (noncontinuous aggregate demand, special endowments, restricted tax instruments, presence of pure profits or fixed constraints), so efficiency result requires stated assumptions

Practical implications and extensions: (a) no optimal taxation of intermediate goods when private production sectors have constant returns because aggregate efficiency implies final-good taxation suffices; (b) untaxable sectors or equal pricing (tourists, regulated firms) can be handled by regrouping sectors in analysis; (c) international trade, migration, consumption externalities, and consumer capital market imperfections modify demand derivatives and therefore alter optimal tax rules but do not generally overturn desirability of aggregate production efficiency
